title: Between 12 June 2020 and 31 August 2020, what will be the highest number of COVID-19 Hospitalizations in the state of Texas for a single day?
preds: Has surpassed, is now a certainty

And there it is, by a hair right now but likely to grow further. Since this is the question I was most invested in forecasting recently, I'm doing a quick hindsight examination of my rationales. Broadly: pretty good, but also somewhat lucky. I think all five underlying conditions I posited here (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1060600) seem to have been correct, as was the use of slower-but-longer-growth version of first wave NY as my main comparison point. Working from those assumptions, the growth curve was fairly predictable, and my updates (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1064318) seem to have been pretty much on point. Where does the luck come in? If we'd been asked to forecast deaths instead of hospitalizations, I think I would have posited the same underlying conditions and then been very wrong in my forecasts (similarly to how I just can't seem to get a handle on how the data is moving in the AZ ICU question). I'm proud of the reads I made on this question, but I also think the data "played nice" here to an unusual extent, and there are many similar questions I would have been much less accurate on.
They've already broken ten thousand. Their going to see that number go even higher into the fifteen thousand range at least.

Prior: before the recent surge in hospitalizations, daily numbers hovered around 2k. As of July 9th, daily hospitalizations are at 9.6k. This sure, starting around June, has shown little sign of abating. Therefore, given current levels and trajectory, my prior is 10k (ie 100% confidence in the >10,000 bucket). Note the question asks "highest single day" hospitalization so it would be impossible to have any weighting whatsoever in any of the first three smaller buckets.  likelihood: my likelihood only projects a greater number of daily hospitalizations. With summer continuing to draw people outside, an election year, and repeated public statements by Texas officials on reopening (including the Governor), I have little confidence in the state's ability to tame virus infections and hospitalizations anytime soon.  It is very concerning that their ideals blind them to reality.

That the governor and it. governor said they would not go to the Texas GOP meeting in Houston with the mayor then refusing the meeting there, is not made out of thin air. Texans have been 6 inches away from their liquor cabinet and state of emergency for the last few weeks,though neither are mutually exclusive.  : )

The Texas GOP convention was nixed in Houston by the mayor based on health policy, which means thousands of non-Houstonians will not travel to Houston and no labor to mingle with them. Will monitor the issue,

Before the question closes maybe today or tomorrow, I was curious what became from the analyses I have started earlier in June and then abandoned:
(1) 7-d avrg new cases || current hospitalization
est.7,803  ||  est. 10,004	9 July 2020
7,500  ||  9,610	8 July 2020

5,447  ||  5,913	29 June 2020
5,304  ||  5,497	28 June 2020
5,091  ||  5,523	27 June 2020
4,903  ||  5,102	26 June 2020
4,581  ||  4,739	25 June 2020
4,227  ||  4,389	24 June 2020

2,804 || 3,148 19 June 2020
2,610 || 2,947 18 June 2020
2,368 || 2,793 17 June 2020
2,279 || 2,518 16 June 2020
1,927 || 2,326 15 June 2020 There has been a clear trend breach around 29 June 2020, which is linked to increasing daily new cases from approx. 23 June 2020, when the number of hospitalizations started to rise much faster than the 7d-average of cases (the latest coefficient was 1.28). I could only speculate about the reasons for that: maybe the link between hospitalizations and the cases is more immediate than between hospitalizations and an average. On the other hand, a lot of infected people from mid-June on might have underestimated the severity of their disease and flushed into hospital especially late in late June, which coheres with the doctors' observations in Texas. A third explanation may be that the undetected (asymptomatic) positives of mid June 2020 may have had contact with especially vulnerable groups (such as individuals with preexisting conditions, obesity etc.) so that the condition of COVID-19 infected people in Texas deteriorated on average after 25 June 2020. However, this acceleration seems to have come to an end, as the coefficient has plateaud at around 1.28 for the three days after 06 July 2020, which of course does not mean that hospitalizations will sink from now on, but just means that the situation does not get worse ever faster. Anyway, I assumed that new cases will be slightly above 10k (10,036, to be precise) again, this will return an est. value for 7d-average of 7,803 for 09 July 2020. At a constant coefficient of 1.28, this suggests that hospitalizations will be an est. 10,004 cases today for the state of Texas, which would close the question already today with the highest bin. 14 July 2020 200,015				 I draw several conclusions from this:
The actual development was eight to nine days ahead of my "worst" case scenario, so what is going on in Texas now, is my worst worst case scenario/outcome.
+After the first spike in positivity rate on 19 June2020 (21.4%) those in charge should have acted quickly by increasing testing and thus preventing the worst, instead testing has remained half-hearted until as late as 28 June 2020. So officials wasted 9 full days, which is probably the equivalent between an exponential growth-curve and an (almost) linear growth-curve in reality, and by chance the difference between my worst- and my worst worst case scenario. The inertia in TX health department and the chaotic testing environment seem to have messed it all up, maybe with respect to the Rep. campaign rally that was supposed to happen in Houston, TX soon and that is now obviously cancelled/prohibited by Houston mayor. Politics puts people at risk, as easy as this.
+The numbers suggest that instead of one big wave there have been four smaller crests of a wave that rolled over Texas, but this to me is a false impression due to testing seasonality over the weekdays, which makes it harder for everyone to get a true estimate of the true situation in the state and that promotes wrong interpretations and incentives. Testing should instead be distributed as evenly as possible, since otherwise the overall picture will be distorted and blurred, and would result in a mixed messaging not only by politicians but also by the figures. If this continues, they will never find an appropriate way to respond.
+I'm also pretty convinced that the spikes in positivity rate are an artifact that stems from cases related to tests that have been taken many days (or weeks) earlier before the result accidentally turned around on that day and it's been ready to be reported. This shows once more how important and crucial a consistent and orderly testing procedure with accurate and timely results really is. They've messed that up, too. (3)
The other thing that I mentioned somewhere is that it seemed to me that Texas was maybe on the same path as Brazil. So let's compare, how both states were faring after one day and 19 days after they reached about 100,000 cumulative cases: 	Brasil	
03 May 2020	101,147	
04 May 2020	105,222	4,03%
23 May 2020	310,087	206,57%

	Texas	
18 June 2020  99,851	
19 June 2020 103,305	3,46%
08 July 2020	220,564	120,89%
This tells us much about the importance of "initial trajectory" of the spread. Texas is better off than Brazil, but not much.
9286 yesterday, 9610 today. Will likely hit 10,000 tomorrow, Friday at the latest.

The Texas GOP convention is in Houston next week and it is the hottest contagion area. The governor and lt. governor are streaming, which should have indicated a no show to participants, but the committee disagrees and 2-3,000 are going to it.

Just commenting (I was already at 100%) Number today is 9,286.
Upping the forecast. I would be shocked if they don’t hit 10,000 by this weekend.
This looks to be scheduled for Friday at the current pace.
The number of hospitalizations is currently 8,698. With over a month to go and new confirmed cases steadily climbing Texas is likely to see over 10,000 COVID19 related hospitalizations.
Up to 8700. Just doesn’t seem like there’s any turning around at this point to be below 10,000.

I just have to admit defeat here. I thought the summer would slow down the virus and we would see it take of in Texas come autumn which clearly hasn't been the case. For a few days the number of new patients has been increasing more slowly, but with the surge of patients today it seem almost certain the number of patients will exceed 10 000 this or next week. Between 7500-10 000: -57
More than 10 000: +57
To avert this outcome, The Leader Of The Free World would have to be correct that the disease will suddenly vanish on its own very soon.  The smart money is not on this.
doubling rate is ~12 days. Leading indicator of new cases is also still trending up. Near certainty now....

Hospitalizations still rose ~300+ each day the past 2 days with some potential weird reporting due to the holiday. There still exists a slim chance cases fall off quickly but it’s likely going to be difficult to get there with cases still on the rise and positive test rate not falling.  https://public.tableau.com/profile/ckelly2528#!/vizhome/COVIDDashboard-Public/NationalOverview

When I look at the curve of hospitalizations (https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/0d8bdf9be927459d9cb11b9eaef6101f) and compare to to the curve of new cases per day (https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas) I see that they track each other, which isn't surprising.  In round numbers, hospitalizations held steady at about 1750 during May. Meanwhile new positive tests averaged 1167 in May. I'm no mathematician, but I'll call that a 1.5 ratio. I'm no epidemiologist, but I would argue that they will continue to track each other going forward. Currently Texas has a positivity rate of 14% vs about 5-6% in May so if anything I would expect the ratio to be somewhat higher now.  For the last 7 days Texas has averaged 6917 new positive results / day which implies a hospitalization of about 10.4k. If we continue on our current pace we'll pass 10k some time around July 9-12. Why might this not happen?
1) they hit up against a limit of beds: nope, there are over 12k available.
2) if this is the peak and the curve flattens due to bar closures, renewed social distancing efforts etc could we avoid going over 10k? Yes I think that's possible. I give it a 5% probability due to a) this is Texas and they don't like being told what to do; and b) the disease has a lot of inertia, so I assume a peak today in cases would result in a peak for hospitalizations in 1-2 weeks, after we hit 10k.
I do not want to be right. 😢 https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/05/coronavirus-on-track-to-overwhelm-houston-hospitals-in-two-weeks-mayor-says.html
At anything remotely like the current pace, they'll make this number in a week or less.
Model-based forecast. Already above 7,500, of course.

With the current wave just starting to crest and hospitalizations at 6500 and going up by ~10% each day, the 10,000 mark could be broken within a week if things don’t change

July 4th activities may only exacerbate this trend, sadly.
July 1st: 6533 hospitalizations. Hospitalizations are still doubling every ~9-10 days. Expecting the trend to continue for next 1 week atleast.

The behavior in TX is different from NJ and NY, with a much slower hospitalization rate [1,2,3]. With the levels of new cases that TX is seeing, they have about 1/2 to 2/3rds the hospitalizations. The highest daily number of cases that NJ had was 4.5k [2]. It had a peak of 8k for hospitalizations. TX had around 5-6k cases for the last week, and has 6.5k hospitalizations. Perhaps they are finding many more asymptomatic people than NJ was back in April, who don't need hospitalization. The questions now are (1) how much are hospitalizations lagging the cases? and (2) how quickly with the daily cases come down? For (1) NJ hit its peak number of hospitalizations two weeks into hanging around the 4k per day number. With that in mind, we can expect another week of growth based on where we are now. For (2) TX is not going to close down quickly [4], like NJ and NY did. I have a hard time imagine it will stay open as the hospital beds and ICUs fill up, but I'm also not a Texan, so can't speak to the mindset. (1) says another 4500 in the next 7 days, assuming the same daily addition to the number of patients, which easily puts it over 10k. I'm going to hedge a bit, as I don't want to be too pessimistic, but not too much as it is very easy to underestimate this virus. [1] https://forward.ny.gov/daily-hospitalization-summary-region
[2] https://www.nj.gov/health/cd/topics/covid2019_dashboard.shtml
[3] https://www.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6
[4] https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2020/06/28/texas-closed-bars-and-curbed-restaurants-will-that-be-enough-to-stop-the-coronavirus-surge/
Rapid increase today at 600 plus. Texas is starting more government mandated shut downs (good thing). Still need to keep adding more percent chance to the upper bounds.

Today's spike brings the last three days to an average daily increase of 336, which is right in line with the trend from the preceding week. This makes it seem likely that the decrease on 6/28 was just a reporting blip which has now evened out, so I'm reverting my forecast as well.

6,533 as of today (6/30). Experience has shown us that it will take at least a couple of weeks for any policy decisions to begin impacting the overall trend (e.g., NY's number of new cases per day continued to increase well after the state was put into a complete lockdown).  The number of hospitalizations has increased by ~1k over the past two days - at this point it seems feasible that they will cross 10k within 7-10 days.

https://www.chron.com/coronavirus/article/Houston-coronavirus-updates-What-you-need-to-15376259.php
Texas is taking action but compliance might be an issue.

+400 after a slow Sunday. If we take this as +200 each day then things are starting to taper off a bit. Still going to add more weight to upper bars though.  Major counter point is that once hospitalizations taper off, they may taper off very rapidly (good thing, social distancing works). This is what happened in New York. Need to keep an eye on this.

The first day in over two weeks that hospitalizations actually fell. Only by a tiny amount, and Sundays can be very backlogged reporting days, and right now this looks likes an outlier (note that AZ had a massive drop on hospitalizations on 6/26, only for the old trend to resume unabated over the past two days). But it's a big enough break in the trend to warrant a reduction in the forecast, even if I can't think of any compelling reasons it would be the leading indicator of an overall shift.
Stepping up the fifth bucket, new measures won't impact the next week's numbers, unfortunately.

Even with the renewed shutting down of bars and whatnot--but with both widespread noncompliance and premature policy reversal confidently predicted--they'll certainly hit 7,500 within a week or so and 10,000 a couple of weeks after that.  Thanks once again to @bobrown for noodging me to sit down and shut up and run the numbers.

Depending on net. growth rate. But I can’t see how that would suddenly decrease in such a way to not hit the 10k?

At the current rate of increase, I figure TX will be over 7,500 by around the 4th of July.  That puts more than 10k in reach by the middle of July.  What a horror!   TX is shutting down again, but will it be enough?  It will take a minimum of 4 days for any shutdown to show an impact, and more like 2 weeks.   The 4th of July will be a hard time to enforce social distancing/lockdown.  COVID has such a headstart  and people are weary already of restrictions. @bobrown

Plus 360 yesterday. Texas just starting to announce government lockdowns. At 300 a day rise were 8 days away from 7500 threshold. Getting less and less likely to stay below that point.  Reasons to be optimistic remain - hopefully people of Texas started to take actions themselves before the government required it.
Today marked reached 5,102 hospitalizations, eliminating the two lowest categories.
Doubling rate ~9 days is showing no signs of slowing down. Got reinforced even today. Likelihood of higher counts is increasing. Readjusting my forecast

Over the past week there's been an average daily hospitalization increase of 279. Steps are finally being taken to slow spread, but even if they have a significant and immediate effect on public behavior (which seems unlikely to me) we're looking at a minimum of 10 days of increases at the current rate or higher before the data starts to show the effects. 10 more days of 275 per day puts Texas at 7850 hospitalizations, leaving a buffer of only 2150 hospitalizations to completely slow and reverse hospitalization growth. That seems highly unlikely to me, and I view those numbers as an improbably optimistic scenario already.
Latest is 5996 cases per day and rising which means adjusting things is needed. Will it go up another 25%, 50? more. Not sure but the rate of increase is impressive
updating based on recent trend upward.

June 25th: 4739 cases. Texas doubling hospitalization every 9 days. Texas starting to react now but impact won't be felt for another 15-20 days.

Plus another 300 cases today. 4 days in a row of around 300 cases.  If staying on same trajectory, 9 days away from 7500 cases, 17 days for 10000 cases.  Reasons to be optimistic - open table reservations in Texas have been going down even if their state has delayed taking action. Texas is now slowing down reopening.  Reason to be pessimistic - this might be too little too late to avoid really high hospitalizations in line with what happened in New York. Especially when Texas has 2 major cities to contain.

Gov. Abbott just announced his plan to do too little too late. He’s electing to delay further reopening but not dial anything back. If they don’t hit 10k hospitalizations by mid-July I will be pleasantly surprised. This is one forecast where I truly hope I’m wrong. Update 06/28: +421 yesterday. +363 the previous day. +350 the day before. 5,523 total as of yesterday. Even if the increase starts to flatten out in the next week, and starts to drop right around Independence Day, momentum is likely to carry the total past 10k before discharges (and, sorry, deaths) start to exceed admissions. Update 06/30: +620 yesterday to 6,533. Looks like they’ll hit 7,500 by Thursday’s update and 10k by 7/7. The measures they’ve put in place over the past few days won’t show up as reduced hospitalizations for 3-4 weeks.

Hospitalization are over 4,000 with infections on the increase and little effort from the Texas Government to stop the spread. Max hospitalization are around 14,200 which is what they are using for gauging severity.

Today's total for numbers in the hospital is 4,389 [1]. The last few days of positive cases have been in the high 4k - low 5k [2]. When NJ was at that level of cases per day (though they maxed out around 4.5k), they had up to 8k in the hospitals [3]. It seems TX is running behind based on that metric, with fewer people, perhaps, getting sick enough to be admitted. Perhaps they exposure isn't as high as in NJ. 5k cases in the hospital is likely to be crossed in the next few days. While there is some mixed messaging from the gov., he is rolling back some of the reopening activities and allowing tighter local controls [4]. Perhaps that will keep the hospitalizations from reaching the highest end of NJ's number. Moving most of the possibility in the 5k bucket, but moving a bit into the 7.5k, in case Texans prefer not to listen. Cases count: 4092 on 23 June. And it is doubling every 7 days. Could get to 10k+ in next 2-3 weeks.  Also Arizona is already at 85% of the hospital capacity. If Texas goes the same way, ~12k hospitalizations.  Increasing the probability for higher hostitalization case count

7-d avrg new cases  ||   current hospitalization	
3,881  ||  4,092	23 June 2020
3,682  ||  3,711	22 June 2020
3,392  ||  3,409	21 June 2020
3,103  ||  3,247	20 June 2020
2,804  ||  3,148	19 June 2020
2,610  ||  2,947	18 June 2020
2,368  ||  2,793	17 June 2020
2,279  ||  2,518	16 June 2020
1,927  ||  2,326	15 June 2020 There may be some of you remembering the question about the 7 day average of cases in Texas on 13 June 2020... (we were talking about 1,800 at that time long ago). I don't know if this correlation is of particular value to anyone.
To me it seems like the 7-day average of cases (to the left) is some leading indicator of a wave of hospitalizations (to the right) about four to five days ahead. So the jump in hospitalizations on 23 June 2020 may be a result of the growth in cases gathered in the average cases data of 18/19 June 2020. So with 5,489 new cases as of 23 June 2020, and new cases assumed remaining just about constant above 5,000 per day until 28 June 2020, we could observe the 5,000 threshold in hospitalizations cracked on 27/28 June 2020, or maybe end up even slightly higher (5,150 in particular, depending on the actual confirmed cases rate by then). And just to add worse news to the bad, and to end any wishful thinking, or dreams, of herd immunity of Republicans:
There are strong signs, that
- the size of immunity due to antibodies built in the blood of an infected and recovered patient will be proportionate to the severity of symptoms, which means that low symptomatic or asymptomatic persons (80 per cent of the cases) will be provided with a low or insignificant level of protection from a re-infection.
- antibodies found in the blood of recovered patients are less stable over time than initially hoped for/expected, so immunity may be gone after weeks or months again completely.
The only hopes remaining to me seem:
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dexamethasone
Dexamethasone may prove to be a cheap, widely available and appropriate treatment to improve overall health of infected persons in hospitals, and will lower the average severity of COVID-2019 for people in ICU treatment, with shorter average hospitalization as a result.
- Remdesivir could in an alternative application also be used for inhalation through an aerosol, which could then prove more effective than the initially intended treatment as a liquid. If it wasn't for a wonder, the SARS-CoV-2 is set to spiral-circulate across population, until a real, effective, compatible and safe vaccine will be at hand in every nation.

The pandemic, if no steps are taken, will explode far beyond 10k.  So the question isn't how bad will the pandemic be, but :
-what steps will be taken, 
-when, 
-how effective will they be, and 
-how long will it take for them to kick in It seems to me that we're starting to see a 4-way disconnect:  
1)  state leaders who are lifting restrictions
2)  members of the public who do not feel it is safe to lift restrictions and are continuing to distance & isolate
3)  those who trust & respect government institutions (& Faucci) and are carefully complying with restrictions
4)  those who think COVID-19 is fake news, politics, and a mountain that's really a molehill so are not or minimally complying with restrictions I'm expecting the pandemic to be blunted by those in groups #2 and #3, but exacerbated by groups #1 & 4 Which of these groups is larger and more powerful in TX?  I think that State leadership will not re-impose restrictions which will empower group #4.  This will allow the pandemic to continue to grow rapidly, which will then create pressure on the government to re-impose restrictions.  This will lead to a zig-zag pattern of cases.   There will be at least a 3-week delay after any changes are made in restrictions before there will be an impact on stats.  Right now, we're seeing an upsurge in cases because of lifting of restrictions several weeks ago.

See my 6/18 update (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1060600) for my initial reasoning on forecasts that continue to be wildly out of line with the consensus. The underlying conditions I posited in that post seem to be borne out strongly in the data, and I don't quite understand how people are reading recent trends as optimistically as the crowd forecast indicates. Cases and hospitalizations continue to rise at an extremely rapid rate that's only becoming more rapid. It will be at least a week until substantial changes in public policy and/or personal behavior, and it will be weeks after that until those changes are reflected in the hospitalization data. Even then, it will be some time before the curve reverses, rather than just slowing. Texas population size means the ceiling on hospitalizations is frighteningly high. The daily increase in new cases in Texas is now running over 7% and hospitalizations are running a touch behind, growing at over 6%/day. A simple extrapolation shows hospitalizations growing to over 10,000 by mid-July. Given that Texas is implementing no new mitigation as of June 22, other than some local regulations on masks, it is unlikely that the rate of growth will slow materially over the next few weeks. In New York, we saw hospitalizations go from ~6,000 when their lockdown started in late March to the peak at >16,000 on April 13. Texas is on a similar trajectory.  Therefore, I think it is highly likely that Texas will be over 10,000. I would put a meaningful probability on the number being >15,000.

Updating: hospitalizations are rising as well as new cases, and once a patient is admitted, they tend to stay for well over a week, if not longer.

Cases/hospitalizations are rapidly accelerating, and I think there are many strong indicators they will continue to rapidly accelerate: 1. The exponential growth characteristics of viruses. 
2. The lag in case detection and especially hospitalizations. Hospitalizations now reflect cases from at least two weeks ago. Nothing that's happened in the previous two weeks would have slowed spread. This sets a very high baseline for us at the current moment. 
3. Precautions among people and businesses continue to loosen. 
4. Texan governmental response will be extremely slow. At this point it is extremely politically difficult for the Texas government to admit that COVID is becoming problematic in the state, and to impose restrictions designed to slow it. This will mean both of those steps are heavily delayed. 
5. Public response will be extremely slow. Political and personal capital for restrictions was already mostly spent in the initial lockdown, and anti- distancing/mask wearing beliefs are now becoming deeply held partisan positions for a large portion of the population.  All of these factors will build off of each other, which should create a situation of relatively unchecked growth in cases from two weeks ago until some point at least a week or two from now, followed by largely piecemeal and ineffective efforts at containment that will may slow growth but likely won't stop it for at least another several weeks.  I think most people are forecasting Texas as though it is part of a "second phase" of the virus spread, when in fact I think the more accurate perspective is that it is going through the "first phase" that the coasts went through, but delayed by several months. In this case I use NY as my comparison. Conditions in Texas are less favorable for completely unchecked spread, but conditions for limiting the spread when it becomes an obvious problem are also much less favorable, and the population of Texas is much larger. So, slower growth but over a much longer period of time, and while NY topped out at 18k hospitalizations, this forecast only tops out at 10k.

In re-reading the question I realized that I misunderstood it. The question is for the total number of COVID cases in hospital on a given day, not the number of new COVID hospitalizations on a day. So clearly that number is going to be bigger. Today there are 2.5k people in hospitals and 15k beds available. Going back to my original numbers.

I'm revising my estimate down a bit, more in line with the crowd. Two thoughts: 
1) Texas only has about 100,000 hospital beds, of which just about 20,000 were available for COVID patients as of April (https://www.dallasnews.com/news/public-health/2020/04/03/texas-has-20000-hospital-beds-available-for-coronavirus-patients-gov-greg-abbott-says/). So it doesn't seem realistic that even if there were, say, 15,000 patients requiring admission in a single day it would be physically impossible to admit that many patients in Texas. I'll assume the number of available beds could increase with surge capacity (convention centers and so on), but even so admitting more than 10k in a day seems beyond what's reasonable. 2) The number of new cases per day has followed a fairly consistent trajectory in many different countries and many different societies. It reaches a point where people take the steps needed to force the curve back down. That number seems to be around 100 new cases per day per 1M population with 1-day peaks up to around 150-200 / 1M. Texas has a population of 29M, so I expect 7-day averages of cases to not rise above about 3000 / day possibly with peaks up to about 6k. (I question whether that many people could physically be admitted to hospitals in a single day as mentioned above.)

The duration of a hospitalization is critically depending on the h. and support with oxygen etc. happening at the earliest stage possible, and how experienced the ICU team has been being confronted with COVID 19-typical inflammatory systemic and respiratory issues. Both determinants should improve for Texas over the next few months, which will lower the individual duration of hospitalization from an average of 30 days to 24 days (?) before August, however at a large span width of between 8 to 60 days.
Infected people who have been hospitalized in April and May (and now occupy an estimated share of 50% of statewide ICU beds) will be treated with advanced methods to alleviate recovery on the one hand, so 25% this group will be released from hospital by 26 June 2020.
At the same time, the outlook for a recovery gets more slim the longer the hospitalization lasts, so an estimated increased percentage of 25% of the group ("Infected people who have been hospitalized in April and May") will have suffered a lethal outcome (i.e. will have died from COVID 2019) by 26 June 2020, compared to their likelihood of 20% for lethality when they first entered the ICU. In the conclusion to this, I expect 25% of the current patients in ICU in Texas to leave the hospital and to free their bed one way or another before 26 June 2020. These are of course core assumptions for the "net rate of hospitalization" and the speed, at which hospital capacities in Texas will be occupied. Hospitalizations in Texas have been increasing recently.  There are 2,242 hospitalizations statewide as of today (6/13) [1].  The bulk of cases are in the 20-59 age demographic, but the bulk of fatalities are in the 60+ demographic [2].  The number of daily fatalities is not increasing, so it's possible the increase in hospitalizations involves younger patients who can recover and leave the hospital more quickly than older patients.  With Summer coming on, hospitalizations may be near peak (assuming COVID-19 has seasonal characteristics). To give some data points to start with: 
- NY state had a high point of 18,825 hospitalizations in mid-April [1], with about 10k positive cases around that time
- NJ had a high of 8,045 in mid-April [2], with about 3.5k positive cases per day around that time Based on some of my earlier estimates looking at Sweden for positive case load [3,4], TX may have 2.1 - 3k cases per day, with the possibility of spiking to twice that. Using NY and NJ for guidance data points, I'll start by using NJ as the high end, as it is in the right range of case load. NJ has about 10x the population density, though, which may have an effect of how quick the growth is and where the highest total will get to. Current hospitalizations in TX are at 2,242 for today [5]. Based on current trends, and the fact the gov is not halting reopening [6], this is only going to get bigger, though some local areas are giving travel advisories and testing guidance to those who travel to the bigger cities [7], so that may stem the spread to avoid the NJ in April case level. I'll consider 2.5 -5k the low end estimate, and put most of my bet in the middle bin for now. [1] https://forward.ny.gov/daily-hospitalization-summary-region
[2] https://www.nj.gov/health/cd/topics/covid2019_dashboard.shtml

My assumption is that on average there will be an additional net hospitalization trend of about 100 persons per week, i.e. 200 persons being released from hospital, while at the same time 300 will be hospitalized. I assume this effect will continue for the next 9 weeks (9 August 2020) with a slim tendency down in the net hospitalizations (120 down to 70). Then, for most of the time in August the net effect will be zero or less: since everybody is in holiday, sitting at home watching netflix or lying on the beaches, new confirmed infections will fall and together with it, the number of hospitalizations will fall. Latter will fall below release rate from hospital, in combination with an ever increasing death rate in ICU hospitalizations. 9 weeks times 100 hospitalizations on average leaves roughly 2,650 as a result in the maximum.

There were ~20,000 total hospitalizations in NY at one point during the first wave of the pandemic. This was when there were ~10,000 new cases per day. At this point, there are ~2,000 new cases per day in Texas. This shows that (AT THIS POINT), there’s ~20% of the cases in Texas but only ~10% of the hospitalizations NY experienced. Assuming a change in hospitalizations of ~10%, (the rate in NY as stated above), this implies an increase of ~200 beds each day while at this level. The existing hospitalizations are 2,166 as of June 12 and have increased by ~22% from 1,773 on June 2nd. Assuming the rate of increase in cases is constant instead of exponential for simplicity purposes, 200 new hospitalizations (technically the change in hospitalizations) would be 22% higher every 10 days, or eventually reaching ~975 by the end of August. Assuming all else remains constant, the month of August alone would have significantly more than 10,000 total hospitalizations. That said, there are obviously a multitude of other factors, including the rate at which people are released, changes in policy restricting activities, personal adherence to policies or recommendations, etc. Due to the liberty Texas has and the resistance it would likely face reimplementing any lock downs, I believe Taxes will wait as long as possible to act which will therefore allow the coronavirus to spread substantially. So, I believe the number of total hospitalizations will be more than 10,000 at some point prior to August 31st.

Like many states, Texas is doing most everything wrong with respect to Covid-19 in an effort to curtail the economic impact of the shutdown.  Without mandating or encouraging proper precautions, more people will get sick, which will also negatively affect the economy, meaning the worst of both worlds. But, with only about 14,000 hospital beds available as of this writing, the odds that the single day approaches and then exceeds 50% of the capacity will (hopefully) force changes -- but, possibly too late to reverse the immediate impact.

June 11=2166 occupied which is the largest number so far.

TX cases numbers and hospitalizations are on the rise and have been over 2000 for the past 3 days. Greg Abbott, the Governor, has repeatedly said and shown that he will not take action to secure the safety of Texans against COVID-19 because "the economy." TX has 13,645 hospital beds available statewide; only 1508 are ICU beds. While it is definitely possible that cases requiring hospitalizations will exceed 5,000 during this time period, TX doesn't have the ICU capacity to handle it. Further evidence to support this forecast: https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/06/16/878924556/as-texas-coronavirus-cases-reach-new-high-gov-abbott-plays-down-the-numbers
June 9=2153 occupied which is the largest number so far. I assume the labor day holiday exposure is driving the current admissions. The full effect of opening should be felt this month or next.
